revision.comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta2)
revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=October 2013}} [[Image:Flickr - boellstiftung - Trevor Phillips.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Then [[Commission for Racial Equality]] head [[Trevor Phillips]] criticised the rejection of his daughter who attended the independent [[Westminster School]].{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2003/mar/10/highereducation.accesstouniversity | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Donald | last=MacLeod | title=Bristol rebuts bias claims by CRE head | date=2003-03-10}}]] The '''University of Bristol admissions controversy''' refers to an historic dispute over the admissions process for the [[University of Bristol]] in the United Kingdom which occurred in 2003.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2003/mar/05/highereducation.accesstouniversity |title=Funding chief backs Bristol in access row | ''The Guardian''. |work=The Guardian |date= 2003-03-05|accessdate=2009-08-25 | location=London}} The 2003 incident was caused by concerns over bias in the admissions system that were perceived as favouritism towards state school studentsIn the United Kingdom a state school is a government funded school which provides education free of charge to pupils. In official literature they are known as maintained schools and include a wide variety of schools including faith based schools and grammar schools. All schools which are not state schools are independent schools. See [[State school]]. after the rejection of some students with strong academic records{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/2798507.stm |title=UK | Bristol denies admissions bias |publisher=BBC News |date=2003-02-26 |accessdate=2009-08-25}} who attended [[independent school (United Kingdom)|independent school]]s.In the United Kingdom a public school refers to a privately funded school funded by the payment of tuition fees. The terms "private school", "public school" and "independent school" are used fairly interchangeably to refer to fee paying school which operate free of the state although "public school" is usually reserved for the leading fee charging independent schools. In the United States the term "public school" refers to government funded schools. See [[Public school (government funded)|Public school]]. The University's widening participation policy allowed the awarding of slightly lower offers to promising applicants from schools with lower academic achievement. Controversy surrounding this policy resulted in a brief boycott of the University by some independent schools and intense media debate about the fairness of the admissions policy as well as praise and criticism of the policy and the boycott from politicians, student leaders and education groups. The boycott was lifted after two months when the Independent School's Council expressed satisfaction with the fairness of the admissions system.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2003/apr/29/publicschools.schools | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Private schools lift Bristol ban | date=2003-04-29 | accessdate=2010-05-27}} Two years later a survey of independent schools concluded that: "It is likely that rejections which may have seemed discriminatory to parents and schools have in fact, been due to a large rise in suitably qualified applicants"{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2005/aug/17/schools.accesstouniversity |title=Private schools admit no bias in university selection | ''The Guardian''. |work=The Guardian |date= 2005-08-17|accessdate=2009-08-31 |location=London | first=Polly | last=Curtis}} and independent evidence was compiled suggesting that claims of bias were wildly exaggerated.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/education-news/bias-against-private-pupils-at-bristol-is-wildly-exaggerated-592296.html|title=Bias against private pupils at Bristol is 'wildly exaggerated' - Education News, Education |work=The Independent|date=2003-03-25 |accessdate=2009-08-25 | location=London | first=Richard | last=Garner}} The controversy has now been superseded by the reality that all British Universities have active 'widening participation' policies designed to increase University applications from lower-achieving schools which tend, de facto, to be state schools. ==Context== [[Widening participation]] is a Government policy in the United Kingdom which attempts to widen access to higher education by increasing numbers of under-represented groups including ethnic minorities, disabled people and those from lower income families. Widening participation is a strategic aim of the [[Higher Education Funding Council for England]],{{cite web|url=http://www.hefce.ac.uk/widen/ |title=Widening participation |publisher=HEFCE |date=2009-10-02 |accessdate=2010-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100924065007/http://hefce.ac.uk/widen/ |archivedate=2010-09-24 |df= }} the body which allocates funding to Universities. The Bristol admissions dispute is one of two policial controversies over widening participation that occurred during the 2000s. In 2000 the [[Laura Spence Affair]] involved the rejection of a state school student who applied to study Medicine at Oxford University and resulted in similar debate about widening participation.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-21466/Laura-Spence-row-flares-again.html |title=Laura Spence row flares again |work=Daily Mail |accessdate=2009-08-31 | location=London}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/education-news/lies-damned-lies--and-laura-spence-698277.html |title=Lies, damned lies - and Laura Spence - Education News, Education |work=The Independent |date=2000-06-08 |accessdate=2009-08-31 | location=London | first=Lucy | last=Hodges}} Bristol University first introduced a widening participation scheme in 1999 after the [[Dearing Report]],{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/higher/does-bristol-pick-the-best-599673.html |title=Does Bristol pick the best? - Higher, Education |work=The Independent |date=2003-03-06 |accessdate=2009-08-31 | location=London}} a report which gave recommendations to the government on the expansion and funding of the British higher education system. Bristol's policy was in part a result of this report as well as being a principled attempt by the University to attract applications from state schools, something Bristol has traditionally struggled to do.{{cite news|author=Prof Eric Thomas, Bristol University |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/1768564.stm |title=UK | Elite uni aims to broaden its appeal |publisher=BBC News |date=2002-01-18 |accessdate=2009-08-31}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2009/feb/03/universities-admissions-social-mobility |title=White, middle-class families dominate top university places | Education |work=The Guardian |date= 2009-02-03|accessdate=2009-08-31 | location=London|first=Jessica | last=Shepherd}} The aims of the 1999 Participation Strategy were to: *Increase applications from students from under-represented groups{{cite web|url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:xTsV_1RLpi0J:www.bristol.ac.uk/academicregistry/raa/wpur-office/strategy-documents-publications/wpstrategy.doc/+WIDENING+PARTICIPATION+STRATEGY+1999+BRISTOL&cd=2&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=uk |title=University of Bristol |publisher=Webcache.googleusercontent.com |accessdate=2010-09-19}} *Put in place an admissions system to enable admissions tutors to identify and make offers to applicants from under-represented groups who have the potential to complete our programmes successfully, with the aim of increasing the number of entrants from such groups *Ensure that students from under-represented groups are given the support they need to achieve the learning outcomes and feel comfortable at Bristol, and to encourage integration of students from all backgrounds. The University's widening participation policy was reviewed in 2001 when a report called ''The Way Forward'' set out how the University could meet [[HEFCE]] participation targets. Under the access initiative each UCAS applicationIn the United Kingdom, applicants apply to University through the [[Universities & Colleges Admissions Service]]. Offers to study may be awarded and these are either conditional on exam performance (e.g. an offer of AAA at [[A-level]]) or unconditional. If an applicant does not meet their offer then a University may reject an applicant. A University need not make the same level of offer to all applicants. See [[UCAS]] to Bristol was examined centrally before being passed to University Departments. Applications from schools where the average [[A-level]] grades were less than CCC were "flagged-up" to alert tutors to disadvantage. Bristol's state intake increased from 49.3% in 1998 to 60% in 2003 under the scheme.{{cite web|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=175041§ioncode=26 |title=Bristol 'proud' of state pupil surge|work=Times Higher Education |date=2003-02-28 |accessdate=2009-08-31}} Bristol has been described as "one of the most competitive universities to get into".{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/low/education/1768564.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=Elite uni aims to broaden its appeal | date=2002-01-18| accessdate=2010-05-27}} At the time of the controversy the university had the third highest private school intake (only [[Oxbridge]] was higher{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/3022418.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=Student hopefuls descend on Bristol | date=2003-06-26 | accessdate=2010-05-27 | first=Dickon | last=Hooper}}) with only 57% of students coming from state school backgrounds.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/1768564.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=Elite uni aims to broaden its appeal | date=2002-01-18 | accessdate=2010-05-27}} This has led some to label it elitist. In 2003 it was reported that the University has 39,000 applicants for its 3,300 undergraduate places each year. In 2002 Bristol had 2,000 students were hunting 100 places in history, and 1,500 students of English chasing only 47 places, leading ''[[The Guardian]]'' to argue that many well qualified students would be disappointed. ==Boycott== Accusations of bias were first made in 2002 when the [[Headmasters' and Headmistresses' Conference]] stated that the admissions procedures for [[University of Bristol|Bristol]], [[Durham University|Durham]], London School of Economics, Manchester, UCL and Edinburgh should be examined for bias.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/2288265.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=Private schools claim university bias | date=2002-09-30 | accessdate=2010-05-27}} The boycott of the University was announced on 4 March 2003{{cite news|author=Rebecca Smithers, education correspondent |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2003/mar/05/highereducation.politics |title=Private schools boycott Bristol over selection | UK news |work=The Guardian |date= 2003-03-05|accessdate=2010-09-19 | location=London}} by the [[Headmasters' and Headmistresses' Conference]] and the [[Girls' Schools Association]] who expressed concern that the admissions policy could lead to the "apparently arbitrary rejection of well-qualified candidates".{{cite news| url=http://education.guardian.co.uk/universityaccess/story/0,,907273,00.html | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Bristol faces boycott over admissions row | date=2003-03-04 | accessdate=2010-05-27}} In a joint statement they said:
In these circumstances, we must send a clear message to Bristol. We cannot recommend to our colleagues that they should encourage young people to apply to Bristol until such time as the university can assure us that its procedures are fully documented, fair, objective, transparent and consistently applied.{{cite news| url=http://observer.guardian.co.uk/education/story/0,,910012,00.html | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Whose university place is it anyway? | date=2003-03-09 | accessdate=2010-05-27 | first=Edward | last=Gibbes}}
However, as it is students who decide which Universities to apply to it was not possible for private schools to prevent their students from applying to Bristol. The "boycott" amounted to schools discouraging sixth formers from applying to Bristol.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/2818263.stm |title=UK | Private schools 'boycott' Bristol |publisher=BBC News |date=2003-03-04 |accessdate=2009-08-31}} ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'' described an academic boycott of this kind as "unprecedented".{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1423753/Private-schools-in-Bristol-boycott.html | work=The Daily Telegraph | location=London | title=Private schools in Bristol boycott | first=Liz | last=Lightfoot | date=2003-03-05 | accessdate=2010-05-27}} Among the rejected candidates cited as evidence of bias was Rudi Singh a student at [[King Edward's School, Birmingham|King Edward's School]]. Singh was rejected from Bristol yet accepted to the [[University of Cambridge]]. Four students with 10A*s at [[GCSE]] and 4 As at [[A-level]] were rejected. Two had attended [[Bedford School]]. One student, Mark Smith, gained 9 A*s at GCSE and was predicted 3 As at A-level yet had his application rejected.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2003/feb/25/highereducation.accesstouniversity |title=Bristol accused of state school bias | ''The Guardian''. |work=The Guardian |date= 2003-02-25|accessdate=2009-08-25 |location=London}} Sushila Phillips, a student at [[Westminster School]], was rejected from Bristol despite gaining a mark of 296 out of 300 in AS level English.{{cite news|last=Syal |first=Rajeev|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1424109/Race-equality-chairmans-daughter-is-refused-admission-because-she-went-to-private-school.html|title=Race equality chairman's daughter is refused admission 'because she went to private school' |work=The Daily Telegraph|date=2003-03-09 |accessdate=2009-08-31 | location=London}} Phillips later stated that she did not believe that she had been rejected because she attended Westminster School and that it was important that Bristol had control over its admissions system.{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/letters/3588910/Trust-the-system.html | work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London | title=Trust the system | first1=Sushila | last1=Phillips | date=2003-03-16 | accessdate=2010-05-27}} ==Reaction== ===University of Bristol=== The University denied any discrimination in the admissions process but reserved the right to take the educational background of students into account when assessing their A-level grades.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2003/mar/04/highereducation.accesstouniversity |title=Bristol attacks admissions 'fallacy' | ''The Guardian''. |work=The Guardian |date= 2003-03-04|accessdate=2009-08-25 |location=London}} In a written response to the Independent Schools Council, Vice-Chancellor [[Eric Thomas (academic)|Eric Thomas]] stated that the University did not operate a quota system for students from any particular school or social background:
The university does not practice unfair discrimination, it [Bristol] does not operate quotas and it will continue to recruit exceptionally able students from all backgrounds through a selection process that is as fair and straightforward as we can make it. Pupils, not schools, make the decisions about which universities to apply to and we are confident that they will continue to want to study at Bristol.[http://www.bris.ac.uk/news/2003/135 Bristol University | News from the University | Admissions policy]
The University highlighted the fact that it is one of the most popular in the country with over 39,000 students for 3,000 places in 2002. In History, English, Economics and Law competition is so fierce that over 30 students can be competing for one place. In English there were 47 places and 1500 applicants of whom 500 had a perfect A-level score of AAA at A2, meaning that many top candidates were rejected.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2003/mar/20/highereducation.accesstouniversity |title=A silent revolution | ''The Guardian''. |work=The Guardian |date= 2003-03-20|accessdate=2009-08-31 | location=London | first=Adam | last=Fox}} [[Eric Thomas (academic)|Eric Thomas]] also emphasised the work the University was doing to "reach out" beyond the middle-classes. In a BBC interview he stated:
a huge raft of initiatives have been implemented. Things like summer schools in which we bring students to the university during the summer to see it, we have relationships with local schools and further education colleges.
The [[University of Bristol]] stated that it is against any kind of discrimination in the admissions process{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/3014108.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=Bristol remains firm on admissions |date=2003-06-23 | accessdate=2010-05-27}} and that the policy of making lower offers to exceptional students from state schools and disadvantaged backgrounds was not to satisfy the government or gain funding:
There is no question of the University attempting to widen participation in order to gain Government cash. Bristol agreed its widening participation strategy in 1998 - long before widening participation became part of Government policy. Work in this field is resource-intensive and funding from the Government helps to cover the costs. The University is not motivated by money but by the desire to recruit the best students and by the recognition that if it is to act fairly and avoid missing out on some of the most able people, it must have regard to factors in addition to predicted A-level grades.
Newspapers reported that the admissions controversy created tensions between state and private school pupils at the University. Gus Glover a candidate who lost that year's [[University of Bristol Union]] Presidential Election attributed his loss to supporting the admissions policy.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2003/mar/09/highereducation.students | work=The Guardian| location=London | title=Inside a university challenged | first=Amelia | last=Hill | date=2003-03-09 |accessdate=2010-05-27}} However, residents of [[Wills Hall]] wrote letters to the newspaper defending the hall against accusations of [[classism]].{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2003/mar/16/letters.highereducation | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Positive discrimination? Don't insult me | date=2003-03-16 | accessdate=2010-05-27}} ===Head teachers=== The [[National Association of Head Teachers]], a [[trade union]] which represents [[head teacher]]s in the United Kingdom{{cite web |url=http://www.naht.org.uk/welcome/about-naht/ |title=NAHT About NAHT |publisher=Naht.org.uk |accessdate=2009-08-31 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090815065228/http://www.naht.org.uk/welcome/about-naht/ |archive-date=2009-08-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }} stated that the "HMC and GSA are guilty of gesture politics of the worst kind... They are merely shooting themselves in the foot by pursuing a boycott". ===Media commentators=== The ''[[Daily Mail]]'' and the ''[[Daily Express]]'' criticised the admissions policies in their headlines.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2003/mar/04/leadersandreply.mainsection |title=Leader: Admission charges | Politics |work=The Guardian |date= 2003-03-04|accessdate=2009-08-25 | location=London}}{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/debate/columnists/article-230000/These-insidious-social-engineers-destroying-merit-aspiration.html |title=These insidious social engineers destroying merit and aspiration |work=Daily Mail |date=2003-02-26 |accessdate=2009-08-25 | location=London | first=Melanie | last=Phillips}} The ''Daily Mail'' greeted the story with the headline "Insidious social engineering destroying merit and aspirations" and the ''Daily Express'' stated "More students being turned down for being middle class". Journalist [[Simon Heffer]] wrote in the ''Daily Mail'' that he was pleased that "at last the middle-class are fighting back".{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/debate/columnists/article-228972/Why-middle-classes-enough.html |title=Why we middle classes have had enough |work=Daily Mail |date=2003-03-05 |accessdate=2009-08-31 | location=London | first=Simon | last=Heffer}} He went on to state the controversy could damage Bristol's academic reputation:
So some of Britain's top schools are going to 'black' Bristol University for the pernicious social engineering policies it has admitted pursuing. Although this news will probably be treated with glee by the tinpot Trotskyists who run Bristol's admissions policy, it can only bode ill for that university. Denied countless high-calibre students who will then go off to adorn rival establishments, Bristol can only decline,
The then-head of the [[Commission for Racial Equality]] [[Trevor Phillips]] expressed surprise that his daughter had been rejected. In ''[[The Times]]'' he stated "Though I have no disagreement with greater access, I would have hoped universities and the government would have a slightly more sophisticated policy than simply 'blacklisting' independent schools".{{cite news| url=http://education.guardian.co.uk/universityaccess/story/0,,911366,00.html | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Bristol rebuts bias claims by CRE head | date=2003-03-10 | accessdate=2010-05-27 | first=Donald | last=MacLeod}} ===Politicians=== Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]] commented on the controversy, stating that university should grant places on the basis of merit rather than class.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2003/mar/06/uk.highereducation |title=Clarke attacks Bristol boycott | Politics |work=The Guardian |date= 2003-03-06|accessdate=2009-08-25 | location=London | first=Rebecca | last=Smithers}} He added that he wanted to see more working-class people in higher education{{cite web|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/article-3667479-details/Blair+wades+into+university+row/article.do |title=Blair wades into university row |work=London Evening Standard |accessdate=2009-08-25}} but was forced to backtrack from comments made by [[Margaret Hodge]] which argued that Universities such as Bristol should be set formal targets for widening access. [[Charles Clarke]], then the Education Secretary, described independent school criticisms as "ill-informed brouhaha"{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2003/mar/05/highereducation.schools |title=Clarke dismisses 'brouhaha' over Bristol admissions | ''The Guardian''. |work=The Guardian |date= 2003-03-05|accessdate=2009-08-25 | location=London | first=Donald | last=MacLeod}} and told schools to ignore the boycott.{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-98448128.html |title=Ignore university boycott, heads told. - Daily Mail (London) |date=2003-03-06 |accessdate=2010-09-19}} He also stated that it would be inappropriate for government to become too involved in university admissions.{{cite news| url=http://education.guardian.co.uk/universityaccess/story/0,,908148,00.html | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Clarke dismisses 'brouhaha' over Bristol admissions | first=Donald | last=MacLeod | date=2003-03-05 | accessdate=2010-05-27}} The then Shadow Education Secretary [[Damian Green]] accused the government of trying to "fiddle admissions for political ends".{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2003/mar/09/uk.highereducation | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Whose university place is it anyway? | first=Edward | last=Gibbes | date=2003-03-10}} [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrat]] MP [[Phil Willis]] said that "social engineering is coming ahead of merit and the development of talent." [[Sir Howard Newby]] chief-executive of the [[Higher Education Funding Council for England]] (HEFCE), the university funding body argued that Bristol's admissions policies were fair and accused sections of the media of becoming involved in a "moral panic" over [[positive discrimination]].{{cite web|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=175152§ioncode=26 |title=Update: 14:25 |work=Times Higher Education |date=2003-03-05 |accessdate=2009-08-25}} ==Resolution== The controversy resulted in applications to Bristol falling for the first time in a decade in the 2004/05 admissions cycle.{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/3326937/University-feels-pinch-after-boycott-by-schools.html | work=The Daily Telegraph | location=London | title=University feels pinch after boycott by schools | first=Roya | last=Nikkhah | date=2004-02-20 | accessdate=2010-05-27}} Application numbers fell by 5% although Bristol downplayed this attributing the decrease to random fluctuations in the level of applications.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/3326937/University-feels-pinch-after-boycott-by-schools.html | work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London | title=University feels pinch after boycott by schools | first=Roya | last=Nikkhah | date=2004-02-20 |accessdate=2010-05-27}}{{cite web|url=http://www.studentadviser.net/articles/bristol.htm |title=Is the Bristol boycott biting? |publisher=Studentadviser.net |date=2004-01-31 |accessdate=2009-08-25}} The boycott ended on 29 April 2003 when the chairman of the [[Headmasters' and Headmistresses' Conference]] expressed satisfaction with the admissions policy for Bristol. In response to the controversy the University introduced a new, more transparent admissions policy.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2003/jun/20/highereducation.students |title=College to revise admissions policy | UK news |work=The Guardian |date= 2003-06-20|accessdate=2009-08-31 | location=London | first=Rebecca | last=Smithers}} In 2005, the [[Independent Schools Council]] published a report which cleared Bristol of bias.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/4161100.stm |title=UK | 'No bias' against private pupils |publisher=BBC News |date=2005-08-17 |accessdate=2009-08-31}}{{cite web|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=197933§ioncode=26 |title=No bias against independent sector applicants by elite institutions, survey finds |work=Times Higher Education |date=2005-08-19 |accessdate=2009-08-31}}{{cite web |url=http://www.isc.co.uk/publication_4_0_0_26_80.htm |title=Independent Private Schools - Independent Schools Council |publisher=Isc.co.uk |date=2005-08-17 |accessdate=2009-08-31 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120205739/http://www.isc.co.uk/publication_4_0_0_26_80.htm |archive-date=2008-11-20 |dead-url=yes |df= }} The report surveyed applications by 20,000 private school pupils and found that in 60 of 300 courses surveyed 98% of private school pupils were offered a place. ==Subsequent developments== {|border="0" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto; width: 40%;" class="wikitable" |- !Year !State intake (%) |- |2002/3 ||63.8|| |- |2003/4 ||65.2|| |- |2004/5 ||64.1|| |- |2005/6 ||65.1|| |- |2006/7 ||63.1|| |- |2007/8 ||61.5|| |- |2008/09 ||61.5|| |- |2009/10 ||60.9 || |- |2010/11 ||60.2{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/educationnews/9946510/Half-of-top-universities-cut-state-school-admissions.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Graeme | last=Paton | title=Half of top universities 'cut state school admissions' | date=2013-03-21}} || |- |2011/12 ||59.9|| |- |} In 2009 Bristol rejected giving a "head start" to applicants to disadvantaged backgrounds as part of a scheme proposed by [[Lord Mandelson]].{{cite web |author=kmccormick |url=http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/news/Bristol-University-won-t-change-admissions-policy/article-1485306-detail/article.html |title=Bristol University admissions | Bristol news |publisher=Thisisbristol.co.uk |accessdate=2010-09-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091109022249/http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/news/Bristol-University-won-t-change-admissions-policy/article-1485306-detail/article.html |archive-date=2009-11-09 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Statistics available from the [[Higher Education Statistics Agency]] published in 2008 show that Bristol's state intake stood at 63.1% a decrease from 65.1% the previous year.{{cite news|last1=Frean|first1=Alexandra|title=Fewer state school students at top universities despite costly campaigns|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/education/article4069357.ece|accessdate=17 October 2015|work=Times|date=5 June 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202215407/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/education/article4069357.ece|archivedate=2 December 2008}} Data from 2009/2010 shows Bristol's intake from state schools and colleges to be 60.0%{{cite news|last=Rogers |first=Simon |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/datablog/2010/apr/16/university-participation-hesa-state-school |title=How many people from state school go to your university? | ''The Guardian''. |work=The Guardian |date= 2010-04-16|accessdate=2010-09-19 | location=London}} an identical figure to 2003 when the controversy over admissions occurred.{{cite web|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=175041§ioncode=26 |title=Bristol 'proud' of state pupil surge |work=Times Higher Education |date=2003-02-28 |accessdate=2010-09-19}} In 2012 the University introduced a points based admissions system whereby poorer students “will be given an automatic weighting to their total academic score”.{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/universityeducation/9450533/Universities-accused-of-socially-engineering-intakes.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Julie | last=Henry | title=Universities accused of socially engineering intakes | date=2012-08-05}} During the 2012/13 admissions cycle all undergraduate courses used some form of contextual data but the university has refused to state exactly how their scoring system works. In 2013 the head of the [[Headmasters' and Headmistresses' Conference]] Chris Ramsay said that independent schools could consider a repeat of the 2003 'boycott' if access agreements agreed by the [[Office for Fair Access]] led to systematic discrimination against applicants from independent schools.
“We can influence [universities’] behaviour by advising good students to go or not to go to them, and that’s obviously something that I suspect is very relevant to them...There was a period just under a decade ago where we in independent schools advised students not to apply to Bristol and they didn’t like that. It definitely had an impact. If in the end we felt that a university was systematically operating its admissions in a way which was disadvantaging the candidates for whom in the end we speak, we might say that.”{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/universityeducation/9580257/Public-schools-threaten-university-boycott.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Graeme | last=Paton | title=Public schools threaten university boycott | date=2012-10-01}}
==Notes and references== ;Notes {{reflist|group="n"|30em}} ;References {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * Bibbings,Lois S, [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=881876 Widening Participation and Higher Education], Journal of Law and Society, Vol. 33, No. 1, pp. 74–91, March 2006, ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070404203330/http://www.bristol.ac.uk/university/governance/policies/admissions-policy.html The new University of Bristol admissions policy] *[http://www.bristol.ac.uk/wideningparticipation/ Widening Participation at Bristol] {{University of Bristol}} {{Widening Participation in the United Kingdom}} [[Category:Education scandals and controversies]] [[Category:University of Bristol]] [[Category:University and college admissions]] [[Category:Education in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Race and education]]

revision.comment: /* Washback effect in English language assessment */
revision.text:
{{distinguish|text='''washback''', the large vessel used in the processing of [[Scotch whisky]]}} '''Washback effect''' refers to the impact of testing on curriculum design, teaching practices, and learning behaviors.{{cite journal|last1=McKinley & Thompson|title=Washback Effect in Teaching English as an International Language|journal=TESOL Encyclopedia of English Language Teaching|date=Feb 2018|volume=1|url=http://www.englishappliedlinguistics.com/uploads/2/4/1/9/2419477/washback_effect_in_teaching_english_as_an_international_language_author_version.pdf}} The influences of testing can be found in the choices of learners and teachers: teachers may teach directly for specific test preparation, or learners might focus on specific aspects of language learning found in assessments. Washback effect in testing is typically seen as either negative, or positive (sometimes referred to as ''washforward''). Washback may be considered harmful to more fluid approaches in [[language education]] where definitions of language ability may be limited; however, it may be considered beneficial when good teaching practices result. Washback can also be positive or negative in that it either maintains or hinders the accomplishment of educational goals. In positive washback, teaching the curriculum becomes the same as teaching to a specific test. Negative washback occurs in situations where there may be a mismatch between the stated goals of instruction and the focus of assessment; it may lead to the abandonment of instructional goals in favor of test preparation. The effect of a test on learning and teaching is a concept discussed as early as the 19th century. Research into washback can be traced back to the early 1980s, when the influence of tests on teaching and learning was first seen as a potential source of [[bias]] due to the accountability of test [[feedback loop|feedback loops]]. As the results of tests became more important to students ([[gatekeeper|gatekeepers]] to future prospects), teachers (evaluation), schools (funding), and states (lawsuits), test preparation as a function of teaching became essential. Tests were made to be economical, using [[multiple choice|multiple-choice questions]] and focusing on [[psychometrics|psychometric]] validity, but perhaps not measuring more complex abilities. Schools and teachers were accountable for student test performance, and thus focused on the skills and outcomes that the tests measured. Given the dynamic interaction between testing and education, the term systematic validity was used to refer to the ways in which a test leads to changes in instruction intended to develop cognitive skills that are being measured by a test.
Research has shown the variable extent to which washback influences different individuals in different ways, and the difficulty of targeting washback. Significant variability has been noted in the ways that teachers respond to test changes and classroom assessments. Effects may be superficial, indirect, and unpredictable due to individual differences in the way that learning is mediated by teachers, textbook writers, and publishers.{{cite journal|last1=Andrews, Fullilove, & Wong|title=Targeting washback—a case study|journal=System|date=2002|volume=30|issue=2|pages=207-223|doi=10.1016/S0346-251X(02)00005-2}} ==Washback effect in English language assessment== With [[globalization]], the world has witnessed an increase in [[Internationalization of Higher Education]], which has resulted in a dramatic increase in the number of international students in the last 25 years. The prominence of English alongside this internationalization process has also seen the use of international tests of English such as [[TOEIC|Test of English for International Communication (TOEIC)]], [[TOEFL|Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL)]], and [[IELTS|International English Language Testing System (IELTS)]] as standard tools in the wider learning community. The increasing weight of these tools in education raises questions about the impact of such tests on teaching and learning, with suggestions that language skills are suffering due to the impact of tests. As English as an International Language (EIL) continues to become more stable through the establishment of clearer features of context-driven English, it is inevitable that there will be significant debate on language norms and proficiency regarding teaching and assessment. The field of applied linguistics should expect to see more specific discussion on the recognition of the way language norms are influenced by use and context, but this remains an unsolved problem in the area of [[language assessment]]. == See also == * [[List of language proficiency tests]] * [[Language proficiency]] == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Impact assessment]] [[Category:Educational evaluation methods]] [[Category:Applied linguistics]] [[Category:Language tests]] [[Category:Language education]] [[Category:Language assessment]] [[Category:Unsolved problems in linguistics]]

(2010) | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1963|5|17|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Ödemiş]], [[Izmir]] | disappeared_date = <!-- {{Disappeared date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (disappeared date then birth date) --> | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = | nationality = Turkish | other_names = | ethnicity = <!-- Ethnicity should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = ''[[Turkish Odyssey]]'' | notable_works = | style = | influences = | influenced = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = <!-- Net worth should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | height = <!-- {{height|m=}} --> | weight = <!-- {{convert|weight in kg|kg|lb}} --> | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | religion = <!-- Religion should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | denomination = <!-- Denomination should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | criminal_charge = <!-- Criminality parameters should be supported with citations from reliable sources --> | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website ={{URL|www.serifyenen.com}} | footnotes = | box_width = }}
'''Şerif Yenen''' (born 17 May 1963) is a travel specialist, tour guide, travel writer, film-maker, international keynote speaker and lecturer. He wrote ''[[Turkish Odyssey]]'' in English, the “first guidebook of Turkey ever written by a Turk”.<ref name="traveler">{{cite news | first = | last = | authorlink = | author = | title= Gezginlerin kitabı |trans-title=The Travelers' Book | url = http://hurarsiv.hurriyet.com.tr/goster/ShowNew.aspx?id=-37208 | format= | newspaper = [[Hürriyet]] |date= 7 September 1998 |accessdate= 29 December 2011 |language=tr}}</ref><ref name="Rehberler">{{cite news | first = Hasan | last = Tuzluoğlu | title= Seyahat: Turistin büyükelçisi rehberler |trans-title=Travel: Guides, ambassadors of tourists | url =http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/seyahat/3958295_p.asp | format= | newspaper = [[Hürriyet]] |date= 20 February 2006 |accessdate= 29 December 2011 |language=tr}}</ref>
Yenen gives lectures about travel and Turkish history and culture, the majority of which are in academic communities.<ref name="Smithsonian2">{{Cite web | url = http://residentassociates.org/ticketing/tickets/reserve.aspx?performanceNumber=220810 |title = Topkapi Palace: The Luxe Life, Sultan Style with Reception |accessdate= 29 December 2011|date = 6 November 2010|work =[[Smithsonian (magazine)|Smithsonian]]}}</ref><ref name="Boston">{{Cite web | url = http://www.bu.edu/phpbin/calendar/event.php?id=104765&cid=17&oid=0 |title = Topkapi Palace: The Luxe Life, Sultan Style |date= 8 November 2010 |accessdate= 29 December 2011 | publisher = [[University of Boston]]}}</ref><ref name="Penn">{{Cite web | url =http://www.penn.museum/events-calendar/details/321-turkey-ancient-and-modern.html |title = Turkey: Ancient and Modern |date= 5 November 2010|accessdate= 29 December 2011| publisher =[[Penn Museum]], [[University of Pennsylvania]] Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology}}</ref><ref name="Trakya">{{Cite web | url =http://byhi.kirklareli.edu.tr/0242414164/ii-geleneksek-trakya-turizm-paneli-universitemiz-kultur-merkezi-ust-salonunda-geceklestirilecektir.html |title = II. Geleneksel Trakya Turizm Paneli Üniversitemizde Gerçekleştirilecektir.|trans-title=2nd Thracian Tourism Panel|accessdate= 29 December 2011|date= 15 December 2011| publisher =Kırklareli University|language=tr}}</ref> His guidebooks are used as textbooks or are on suggested reading lists at various universities,<ref name="ozdal">{{Cite web |url =http://w3.gazi.edu.tr/~ozdald |title =Gazi University Turizm İşletme ve Turist Rehberliği Anabilim Dalı |accessdate= 29 December 2011 | last = Değirmencioğlu | first =Yrd. Doç. Dr. A. Özdal |date= | publisher =[[Gazi University]] |language=tr}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url =http://www.balikesir.edu.tr/~bologna/tr/btioyo/turist/mesleki_yabanci_dil3.doc |title =Lisans Programı Ders Tanıtım Formu |accessdate= 29 December 2011 | last = | first = |date= | publisher =Balıkesir University Turizm İşletme ve Turist Rehberliği Bölümü |language=tr}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url =http://files.tulga1.webnode.com.tr/200000015-84637855ea/cografyakapsam.pdf |title =Başkent University, Turizm Coğrafyası Ders Planı |accessdate=29 December 2011 | last =Albustanlıoğlu | first = Dr. Tulga|date= | publisher = Başkent University, Turizm İşletme ve Turist Rehberliği Bölümü|language=tr}}</ref> and his articles and columns are published in international magazines and national newspapers.<ref name="Oryx">{{cite journal | last =| first = | author =Şerif Yenen| authorlink =| title =İstanbul | journal = [[Qatar]] Oryx| pages =48–60| publisher =[[Qatar Airways]] |date= September 2010 | url =http://www.agencyfish.com/Oryx_Magazine_September2010 |accessdate= 29 December 2011 }}</ref><ref name="Aksam">{{Cite web | url = http://www.turkcebilgi.com/kose-yazisi/84498/belekin-cirkin-su-kemerleri |title =Belek'in çirkin su kemerleri |accessdate=29 December 2011|language=tr}}</ref><ref name="TurizmHabercisi">{{Cite web | url = http://www.turizmhabercisi.com/?author=8 |title =Yazar Arşivi |publisher=Turizm Habercisi |accessdate =29 December 2011 |language=tr}}</ref>
==Biography==
===Early life and education=== Şerif Yenen was born into a middle-class family in the town of [[Ödemiş]] near [[Izmir]] in 1963. After completing middle school in Ödemiş, when he was fourteen, he passed the entrance exams and became a military student at the [[Kuleli Military High School]] in [[Istanbul]], where the instruction was mainly in English. After high school he was accepted in the Department of English Literature and Linguistics at the [[University of Istanbul]] as a military student. After graduation from the university in 1985, he became an officer in the [[Turkish Armed Forces|Turkish Military Forces]], and taught [[English as a Second Language|English as a second language]] for four years at the Maltepe Military High School in Izmir. He left the Army in 1989 and attended tourist guide training programs offered by the Ministry of Tourism of Turkey and became qualified as a national tourist guide.
===Career=== While working as a tourist guide, he published his guidebook, ''Turkish Odyssey'' in English (turkishodyssey.com), in 1997. The content and the design of his website gained attention in the media and won numerous awards.<ref name="atak">{{cite news | first = | last = | authorlink = | author = | title= Turizm İnternet atağında | url=http://hurarsiv.hurriyet.com.tr/goster/printnews.aspx?DocID=-254630 | format= | newspaper = [[Hürriyet]] | year = | id = | date= 11 July 1997 |accessdate= 29 December 2011 | söz = | arşivurl = | arşivtarihi = |language=tr}}</ref><ref name="tasarım">{{Cite web | url =http://www.dost.net/bestsite/altin.html | title = En iyi Tasarım ''Turkish Odyssey'' by Şerif Yenen |accessdate= 29 December 2011 | author = | last = | first = | authorlink = |date=March 1998 | publisher =Dost.net |language=tr}}</ref><ref name="webidol">{{Cite web | url = http://www.serifyenen.com/awards_webidol.asp | title = Webidol İkincisi |accessdate= | author = | last = | first = | date= 29 December 2011 | publisher = Web idol |language=tr}}</ref> He published the multimedia version of the same work as a [[CD-ROM]] in 2001.
Yenen has held elected positions on the boards of various organizations in the tourism sector:
* President of the Istanbul Tourist Guides' Guild (IRO) 2002-2015<ref name="IRO"> {{Cite web | url = http://www.tureb.net/index.php/iro/iro-yonetim-kurulu | title = İRO Yönetim Kurulu |accessdate= 29 December 2011 |language=tr}}</ref><ref> {{cite news | first = | last = | title= Daha büyük bir ceketle haydi işbaşına | url = http://hurarsiv.hurriyet.com.tr/goster/ShowNew.aspx?id=111171 | newspaper = [[Hürriyet]] |date= 7 November 2011 |accessdate= 29 December 2011 |language=tr}}</ref>
* President of the Federation of Turkish Tourist Guide Associations (TUREB) 2002 - 2013<ref name="Tureb">{{Cite web | url = http://www.tureb.net/index.php/tureb/yonetim-kurulu | title = TUREB İcra Komitesi | accessdate= 29 December 2011 | author = | last = | first = | authorlink = | date= |language=tr}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | url = http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/tureb-chairman-claims-tourism-suffering-from-lack-of-promotion.aspx?pageID=438&n=tureb-chairman-claims-tourism-suffering-from-lack-of-promotion-2002-07-23 | title = TUREB chairman claims tourism suffering from 'lack of promotion' |accessdate= 10 December 2011 | author = | last = | first = | authorlink = | date= 23 July 2002 | newspaper = [[Turkish Daily News]] }}</ref>
* President of the Tourist Guides Foundation (TUREV), 2002 – 2009<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.tureb.net/index.php/english | title = TUREB |accessdate= 29 December 2011 | author = | last = | first = | authorlink = | date= | publisher = }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | title =Turist Rehberleri Vakfı Genel Kurul Toplantısı Yapıldı | journal = Rehber Dünyası | pages =10 | volume =36 |issue= June 2004 |date= June 2004 | url = http://www.tureb.net/haziran04bulten.pdf |accessdate=29 December 2011 |language=tr}}</ref>
* Executive board member of the World Federation of Tourist Guide Associations (WFTGA),<ref>{{cite news | first = | last = | authorlink = | author = | title= Türkiye'nin vitrininde rehberler var | url = http://hurarsiv.hurriyet.com.tr/goster/ShowNew.aspx?id=169753 | newspaper = [[Hürriyet]] |date= 6 September 2003 |accessdate= 29 December 2011|language=tr}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = http://wftga.org/main.php?page=melbourne_2005 | title = February 21st 2005 is the International Tourist Guide Day|accessdate= 29 December 2011 | author = | last = Roy | first = Ruby | authorlink = |date= 21 February 2005 | publisher = World Federation of Tourist Guide Associations |language=tr}}</ref> and editor-in-chief of the ''Guidelines Internetion@l'' magazine,<ref>{{cite journal | title = Editorial | publisher = Guidelines Internetion@l | pages =3 | issue =8 | date =Autumn 2004 | url =http://wftga.org/guidelines/Guides_Int_2.pdf | accessdate = 29 December 2011 | doi = | jstor = | id = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = http://wftga.org/main.php?page=guidelines_internetional | title = Guidelines International | accessdate= 29 December 2011 | publisher = World Federation of Tourist Guide Associations }}</ref> 2003 – 2007
* Vice President of Turkish Travel Agencies and Tourist Guides Assembly, established as a tourism council within TOBB (The Union of Chambers and Commodity Exchanges of Turkey) 2006 - 2013.<ref>{{Cite web| url = http://www.tursab.org.tr/tr/tursabdan-haberler/tobb-turkiye-seyahat-acentalari-ve-rehberler-meclisi_1799.html | title = TOBB – Türkiye Seyahat Acentaları ve Rehberler Meclisi |accessdate= 29 December 2011 | author = | last = | first = | authorlink = |date= 31 July 2006 | publisher = TÜRSAB |language=tr}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | url = http://www.haberler.com/tobb-turkiye-seyahat-acentalari-ve-rehberler-2506817-haberi/ | title = TOBB Türkiye Seyahat Acentaları ve Rehberler Meclisi Başkanlığı |accessdate= 29 December 2011 |date= 31 January 2011 | publisher = Haberler.com |language=tr}}</ref>
* Member of the Consultative Committee for Istanbul 2010 Cultural Capital of Europe<ref> {{Cite web |url = http://www.ioi.gov.tr/avrupa_kultur_baskenti.php | title = İl Özel İdaresinden 2010 Avrupa Kültür Başkenti İstanbul'a büyük destek. |accessdate= 29 December 2011 | author = | last = | first = |date= | publisher = İstanbul İl Özel İdaresi |language=tr}}</ref>
Yenen regularly wrote a weekly column in the Mediterranean supplement of the Turkish newspaper ''[[Akşam]]'' between 2006 and 2009 under the heading ''A Tourist Guide’s Perspective''.<ref name="Aksam"/><ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.tureb.net/aksamakdeniz.asp | title =Akşam Akdeniz |accessdate=29 December 2011 |language=tr}}</ref>
Şerif Yenen, who has been attracting media attention for his endeavors<ref> {{cite news | first = | last = | authorlink = | author = | title= Değişen seyahat anlayışı ve turist rehberliği | url = http://www.radikal.com.tr/Radikal.aspx?aType=RadikalEklerDetayV3&ArticleID=872143&Date=14.11.2011&CategoryID=42 | format= | newspaper = [[Radikal]] | date= 26 December 2004 |accessdate= 29 December 2011 |language=tr}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first = Ercan | last = Sarıkaya | title= Kılavuzunuz karga olmasın | url = http://arsiv.sabah.com.tr/2004/08/05/gun113.html | newspaper = [[Sabah (newspaper)|Sabah]] |date= 5 August 2004 |accessdate= 29 December 2011 |language=tr}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first = | last = | authorlink = | author = | title= Turist rehberleri yasalarının bir an önce çıkarılmasını istiyor | url = http://www.turizmgazetesi.com/news/news.aspx?id=27468 | newspaper = Turizm Gazetesi |date= 13 March 2006 |accessdate= 29 December 2011 |language=tr}}</ref> as the chairman of IRO and TUREB to make sure that the occupational bill of law for the tourist guides of Turkey is passed by the parliament, played a decisive role in 2012<ref name="LawAward">{{ cite news|title=Şerif Yenen’e Rehberlik Yasası’ndan ödül geldi |url= http://www.turizmhabercisi.com/serif-yenene-rehberlik-yasasindan-odul-geldi.html|newspaper=Turizm Habercisi |date= 10 October 2012 |accessdate= 15 October 2012}} {{tr icon}}</ref><ref name="LawAward2">{{cite news|title=Turizmde yeni trendler: Online turizm, uzak destinasyonlar, sosyal medya |url= http://www.tuyed.org.tr/haberler/turizmde-yeni-trendler-online-turizm-uzak-destinasyonlar-sosyal-medya.html|newspaper=Turizm Yazarları ve Gazetecileri Derneği|date=10 October 2012 |accessdate= 15 October 2012|language=tr}}</ref><ref name="LawAward3">{{cite news|title=SKALİTE ödülleri, 15'inci kez sahiplerini buldu |url= http://www.turizmdebusabah.com/haberler/turizmde-kalite-odullendirildi-skalite-2012de-kazananlar-belli-oldu-foto-galeri-63064.html|newspaper=Turizmde Bu Sabah|date=13 December 2012 |accessdate= 17 December 2012|language=tr}}</ref> during the process of drawing up and passage of the law, which had been much anticipated by the tourist guides for the past 40 years. As a result of his endeavors, the occupational law was promulgated in the [[Official Gazette of Republic of Turkey|''Official Gazette'']] and entered into force on June 22, 2012. Thus, tourist guiding was defined as a profession in Turkey.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.resmigazete.gov.tr/main.aspx?home=http://www.resmigazete.gov.tr/eskiler/2012/06/20120622.htm&main=http://www.resmigazete.gov.tr/eskiler/2012/06/20120622.htm |title=22 Haziran 2012 Tarihli ve 28331 Sayılı Resmî Gazete |date=22 June 2012 |publisher=Turkish Prime Ministers Office |accessdate= 15 October 2012|language=tr}}</ref>
He has given private guide services to celebrities or statesmen, among whom are [[Pope Benedict XVI]],<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.serifyenen.com/pope_pics.asp| title =Pope Benedict XVI |accessdate= 29 December 2011 }}</ref> [[Oprah Winfrey]],<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.serifyenen.com/Oprah_Winfrey_pics.asp | title =Oprah Winfrey |accessdate= 29 December 2011 }}</ref> [[Princess Michael of Kent]],<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.serifyenen.com/princess_pics.asp | title =Princess Michael of Kent |accessdate= 29 December 2011 }}</ref> [[Lester Holt]] from [[NBC Today Show|Today Show-NBC]],<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://video.today.msnbc.msn.com/today/24403829/#24403829 | title =Where in the World is Matt Lauer: A whirlwind tour of Turkey |publisher=[[NBC]] |accessdate = 29 December 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.serifyenen.com/todayshow.asp | title =Today Show-NBC |accessdate= 29 December 2011 }}</ref> etc.
Yenen's second guidebook was the 488-page Quick Guide Istanbul, then started "Istanbul", "Culture" and "Turkey" series of his Quick Guide Pamphlets.<ref>{{cite book|title=Quick Guide Istanbul|isbn=978-975-94638-8-5|page=488|author=Şerif Yenen}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Top 10 Places in Istanbul|isbn=978-605-87-8083-5}}</ref> These are user friendly and informative fold-out pamphlets of museums, monuments and cultural highlights. While working as an active tourist guide, Şerif Yenen gives lectures<ref name="Smithsonian2"/><ref name="Boston"/><ref name="Trakya"/> and training for tourist guides.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.turizmhabercisi.com/?p=10502 |title =Rehberlik kurslarında program yoğun |accessdate=29 December 2011 | last = | first = |date= 14 February 2007 | publisher =Turizm Habercisi |language=tr}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last = | first = | author = | authorlink = | title = Üniversitelerin Rehberlik Bölümleri ile İlişkiler Komisyonu | journal = İRO Bülten | page = 11 | issue =4 | date= April 2011 | url = http://www.tureb.net/nisan11bulten.pdf | accessdate= 29 December 2011 | doi = | jstor = | id = |language=tr}}</ref> In addition to his positions at various tourism organizations, he is consulted on TV programs and juries.<ref>{{cite news | first = | last = | authorlink = | author = | title= İşte İstanbul’un simgesi: Ayasofya | url =http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/pazar/14161422.asp | newspaper = [[Hürriyet]] |date= 21 March 2010 |accessdate= 29 December 2011 | language = Turkish }}</ref><ref> {{Cite news | url = http://hurarsiv.hurriyet.com.tr/goster/ShowNew.aspx?id=243239 | title = Türkiye’nin manzarası en güzel 10 mekanı | accessdate= 29 December 2011 | author = | last = | first = | authorlink = |date= 23 July 2004 | newspaper = [[Hürriyet]] |language=tr}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tXMMvtEOue4 |title =Şerif Yenen Televizyon Röportajları |accessdate=29 December 2011 |language=tr}}</ref>
He has produced a [[travel documentary]] film on Istanbul in 2014: [[Istanbul Unveiled]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Istanbul Unveiled (2013)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2747548|publisher=IMDB|accessdate=28 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Istanbul Unveiled|url=http://www.istanbulunveiled.com/|publisher=Istanbul Unveiled|accessdate=28 January 2014}}</ref> Şerif Yenen gives lessons on Anatolian Civilizations and Cultural Heritage of Turkey at the [[Istanbul Bilgi University|Bilgi]] and [[Boğaziçi University|Boğaziçi]] Universities as a part-time instructor.<ref>{{cite web|title=Prof. Dr. Mehmet Onur Gülbahar’dan turizm öğrencilerine tavsiyeler|url=https://www.turizmgunlugu.com/2018/06/13/prof-dr-mehmet-onur-gulbahardan-turizm-ogrencilerine-tavsiyeler/|publisher=turizmgunlugu.com|accessdate=8 October 2018}}{tr}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Turizm İşletmeciliği Bölümü|url=http://www.boun.edu.tr/tr_TR/Content/Akademik/Lisans_Katalogu/Uygulamali_Bilimler_Yuksek_Okulu/Turizm_Isletmeciligi_Bolumu|publisher=Boun.edu|accessdate=8 October 2018}}{tr}</ref>
